data:
Strathmore Primary School intends to pursue a whole school approach to achieve the national 1+2 strategy for languages learning. The project will support school development to raise attainment and to close the poverty related attainment gap. We hope to raise the expectations and aspirations of our learners, staff and families through the provision of high quality teaching and learning, which is supported in school, at home and in the community. From our youngest learners at Early Level to our Second Level learners who will move on to Forfar Academy, it is important that they all have more confidence in their languages ability. To achieve this, the two participants will deliver languages training for teaching and non-teaching staff, and for families. The number of school staff exceeds 30, plus the families of our 329 learners so the project is wide reaching, with long-term benefits. 

This project offers an unprecedented opportunity for the school to gain learning and teaching resources which make languages learning both engaging and achievable for our learners, as we need teaching staff who are confident in their abilities to deliver quality learning to other members of our school community. Participants will gain an improved understanding of modern French culture and the French education system which cannot be achieved without being in France and interacting with French teaching professionals. This will be shared with school and authority colleagues, enabling learners to have a greater understanding of Europe and their role and responsibilities as global citizens. The use of IT will support both teaching and learning, but also provide opportunities to engage with learners in other countries which has not been undertaken before. 

The two participants have a varying expertise in delivery of modern languages. They are both full time members of staff, who are committed not only to their own professional learning, but to the learning of their colleagues. The training in language and methodology through the immersion courses will help the participants, and subsequently school staff to embed French into the daily life of the school. Subsequently, the school will be in  a much improved position to implement L3 into the school curriculum. 

Activities to engage our families and local community will provide opportunities for staff and learners to share their learning, and enthusiasm for languages. To have the intended impact, we will engage with our whole school community, not just our learners and staff. We intend to do this through family learning events, and community engagement through events and inter-generational learning. To raise the expectations and aspirations of our learners and families, we will raise the importance of learning a modern language through engagement with local businesses who use languages. This will have the impact of making meaningful links with the world of work (DYW national priority) and skills for learning, life and work. 

The longer term benefits of this project include achievement of the national 1+2 strategy, closing the poverty related attainment gap which is very pertinent to Strathmore where more than a third of our learners are in areas of multiple socio-economic deprivation (as measured by SIMD data), and raising the aspirations of our learners and families in a global society. Learning and teaching of modern languages will become embedded into the curriculum, with progression evident throughout the school. Confidence in teaching languages will be higher with all staff recognising the benefits of languages learning for all, not just some. This will help us to achieve equity, not just equality in our provision. By learning languages, our learners will be supported in developing a resilient attitude to learning. This in turn will help to raise attainment.

The project will allow the school to have two teachers training in language and methodology to embed French into everyday teaching and learning at the school.
It will help the school follow the ethos of a Curriculum for Excellence, find partners abroad to work closely with to deliver this and allow pupils to use ICT to communicate with other schools in UK and abroad.
The project will  improve the competencies of the staff member by assisting him to acquire and learn new vocabulary, improve and develop new teaching practices and gain confidence and competence at delivering French within a Curriculum for Excellence. It will enhance understanding, awareness and appreciation of the culture of modern France.
The immersion training offers opportunities to develop new teaching methods and tools. It will develop the confidence of the participant to establish formal links with French schools and allow children from both Scotland and France to develop friendships and bonds and understand similarities and differences in school life and their wider culture.
The staff member identified is a primary school teacher currently working in the second level. He has demonstrated a keen passion for integrating French into his teaching through participation in the  Scottish Government 1 + 2 initiative and other modern language CPD activities. The training offers opportunities for the participant to improve his language competency and enhance his teaching skills to deliver engaging French lessons to primary school aged children.
This will be achieved through assisting the participant to:
• Improve methodological expertise in the teaching of French to young learners
• Acquire materials and ideas suitable for the teaching of the French at primary level
• Develop cultural awareness and understanding of contemporary France, including the education system 
• Improve his competence and performance in speaking and teaching French
• Use relevant, engaging internet and other ICT resources in his class.
The course will provide the participant with greater confidence and ability to teach Modern Foreign Languages and a greater cultural awareness which can be transferred to pupils. It will improve his teaching methodology for languages within the school and embed French on a cross curriculum level. This will allow staff to start teaching French in a more ad hoc way, several times a week rather than just 1 session per week.
All new resources will be placed on a shared drive within the school, to help learning and teaching throughout the school.
The activities will rase awareness of the importance of languages and Europe within the school to pupils, staff, parents and other stakeholders.
There will be ongoing dissemination activities related to mobility to raise awareness.  It is anticipated that new CPD opportunities training materials will be created within school and the cluster. 
Social media, brochures, blogs, press articles in the local newspapers, exhibitions and open events in school will all be used to promote greater awareness of French language learning in the school. Results of the training will have already been communicated to colleagues through presentations and/or workshops at staff training events.
These will impact: 
• Locally –  on staff, pupils and parents.
• Regionally – by transfer of skills within cluster groups
• Nationally – developing the ability to contribute to national language events
• European level – increasing European links with Primary/ Secondary schools

As a result of the recent 1+2 government language policy and the commitment from Angus Council to implement the long term strategy, Whitehills Primary School require their staff members to up-level their language skills. At present, following the introduction of the PLPlatform, we are teaching French throughout all stages of the school. As a result, pupils will be learning French from Nursery to Primary 7 and progressing further with their spoken language skills and vocabulary knowledge than ever before. This requires the need for more skilled, knowledgeable,competent and trained staff members to implement this long term strategy effectively. Spanish has also been identified as our third language and is planned to be taught from summer 2017. Presently, there are no Spanish speaking staff members at Whitehills Primary School and this identified as a development need. The upper stages (P5-P7) require a trained and knowledgeable staff member to help plan and cascade learning and teaching opportunities. 
  The opportunity to attend these courses will enable our school to continue to create close ties to both local and international schools and facilitate networking opportunities between native French and Spanish teachers and ourselves. We aim to achieve this goal through use of E-twinning. The school has currently been working alongside our local language staff tutor to help set up links with primary schools in France and this will be similar to the links created with schools in Spain. Through the immersion experience, staff members will have a deeper and broader understanding of the cultures in both countries, which in turn can be passed on to the pupils in our school. This will develop their curiosity and appreciation of what are the similarities between France / Spain and Scotland. 
  Following attendance on the immersion courses, training CPD events will be held both within our school as well as the opportunity to share and cascade the learning with other colleagues within the area. Parents will benefit as pupils will share their learning through close home-school links in addition to on-going class assemblies, open afternoons and parents evenings. Quality resources can be made more accessible through being placed within a shared staff common area. Continued correspondence with other course participants will further develop and sustain the ongoing progression with staff development.

The Immersion project created by LFEE has been carefully designed so that participants are given the opportunity to develop their language teaching skills, improve their language knowledge and abilities and to deepen their understanding of another culture. These skills will be essential in the successful deliverance of the recommendations of the 1+2 Modern Language policy that is being actively implemented within Angus schools. Knowledge and skills gained will further deepen and enhance the learning experience of the pupils with the future aim of raising the awareness of the importance of Modern Languages in the field of potential future employment of our pupils.

The objectives are to improve the confidence and competence of the participants in order that they can take forward and support the 1+2 initiative across the staff team and with cluster colleagues:

* to enhance our own conversational French and to gain new ideas for the classroom
* to develop and maintain a bank of resources to use in the classroom - ICT/Internet, books, songs and films, etc
* to develop cultural awareness and an understanding of modern day living in France
* to improve pedagogy

The school is applying for places for four members of staff. As a small rural school we are intending that the staff will cascade knowledge gained and be vital in the development of language skills and knowledge within the school and associated cluster schools. One member of staff will use her knowledge gained to direct the development of the school aims in her role as Head Teacher, she has Higher French and is keen to develop her existing cultural knowledge. The three other members of staff applying will have responsibility within their nursery/teaching stage to oversee progression and use skills gained to effectively and progressively deliver the curriculum within both their own classes and those of their colleagues.  The three members of staff have studied languages at secondary school level and have previous experiences of  Modern life in European countries through their travels to the continent.  One member of staff has lived and worked abroad in the past.

The week long Immersion trip will provide daily opportunities to gain further skills in Languages and cultural knowledge through studies of a range of pedagogical techniques, experiences as both teacher and pupil and complete immersion in the language and culture through visits to a range of sites. All of these will greatly improve the individual's skills in the effective teaching of a modern language.

The intensive, week long professional learning experience will provide the practical/interactive model of how to teach modern foreign language effectively.  Therefore, it would be expected that the group of participants from Tannadice come back and put together a series of workshops for staff to bolster the planned improvement work which will be supported by Richard Talleron,  Power Platform. 

The experience will provide us with strong links with practitioners in France and will increase our capacity to 'deliver' French well through better pedagogy, access to resources and materials, ICT and knowledge of modern day France.  It will allow us to work with our children in ways which will motivate them to learn and we will use assessment is for learning (AifL) approaches to check ongoing progress and to set and fulfil next step targets with our children so that our decisions about children's competencies are well placed and the pace of learning suited to ongoing achievements.

The potential long term benefits are extremely positive given that one member of staff is currently seconded to development services within the authority and funded by the Scottish Government as a Staff Tutor for Modern Foreign Languages.  Upon her return, we will be able to tap in to her skills, knowledge and expertise in this area of learning to further support the ongoing learning and development of both children and staff.

We are dedicated to giving our children the very best life chances at Tannadice and our long term goal is to nurture well rounded young people who have a positive outlook to life both in and beyond their local and national environments
Social Innovation in Marginalised Rural Areas

SIMRA seeks to advance understanding of social innovation (SI) and innovative governance in agriculture, forestry and rural development (RD), and how to boost them, particularly in marginalised rural areas across Europe, with a focus on the Mediterranean region (including non-EU) where there is limited evidence of outcomes and supporting conditions. These objectives will be achieved by: 
1. Developing systematic frameworks: a) theoretical - for improved knowledge of the complexity of SIs and its dimensions, and its impact on unfolding territorial capital; b) operational - based on a trans-disciplinary coalition (researchers and practitioners) to advance understanding of preconditions and success factors (e.g. instruments, incentives etc.) for implementing/operationalizing SI. 
2. Creating a categorisation of SIs which encompasses the specificities in terms of social priorities, relationships/collaborations etc. and serves as an instrument to explore reasons why regions with similar conditions display diverging paths and to 'turn diversity into strength’.
3. Creating an integrated set of methods to evaluate SI and its impacts on economic, social, environmental, institutional and policy dimensions of territorial capital.
4.  Co-constructed evaluation of SIs in case studies across the spatial variation of European rural areas, considering which components of territorial capital foster and, or mainstream RD. 
5. Synthesis and dissemination of new or improved knowledge of SIs and novel governance mechanisms to promote social capital and institutional capacity building and inform effective options/solutions for shaping sustainable development trajectories. 
6. Creating collaborative learning and networking opportunities and launching innovative actions at different/multiple scales, with continuous interactions among researchers, ‘knowledge brokers’ and stakeholders to foster and mainstream SI, leaving a durable legacy.
PIP GB - Pearls in Peril - securing the future of the freshwater pearl mussel in Great Britain

The freshwater pearl mussel (Margaritifera margaritifera) is declining dramatically throughout its range and is under grave threat in the UK, as in other areas of its EU distribution. The British populations of the freshwater pearl mussel, which is highlighted for conservation under Annex II of the Habitats Directive, have been adversely affected by multiple issues, including wildlife crime (removal in order to sell the pearls), habitat degradation and declining water quality.

‘Youth Vibes for Europe’ is a multilateral youth exchange between six countries (Italy, Cyprus, FYROM, Ireland, UK and Greece). Growing out of an idea initially formed during an international seminar on youth employment, the project centres on young people developing a healthy leisure time both physically, mentally and in terms of active citizenship as part of an alternative use of their free time.  Participation of young people in making decisions about their own lives is a key element of the project.  Key objectives include exposing our young people to new experiences and opportunities, learning about Europe, engaging in informal learning as a key element of youth work, to develop interpersonal and life skills,  and learn how to be peer leaders and impact our organisations positively.  
There are young people participating who come from a range of backgrounds.  The young people have fewer social and economic opportunities and this project is a real way for them to devleop their skills and atticitued, both in terms of personal development, active citizenship and employability.  Activitites will include participating in physical leisure time activities, programmes to develop mindfulness and resilience and the participation in a youth leadership programme.  Methodologies will include group work, self directed learning, multimedia activiteis and planning and participation in porgrammme development.  The project will result in young people who have a greater understanding of themelves and of other young people from Europe, will result in more confident and socially aware young people who have changing attitudes about the opportunites and options available to them, and will result in young people who are more positive about their future and what they can do to influence it.  It will also impact on the participating organisations who will learn more about participation, policy making and the benefits of international work as a key component to our youth work practice.  
The Youth Exchange will take part between 25/04/2018 and 01/05/2018 in Florina, Greece, Region of Western Macedonia.

Youth Vibes for Europe είναι μία πολυμερής ανταλλαγή νέων μεταξύ έξι χωρών (Ιταλία, Κύπρος, ΠΓΔΜ, Ιρλανδία, Ηνωμένο Βασίλειο και Ελλάδα). Αποτελεί την εξέλιξη μιας ιδέας που αναπτύχθηκε κατά την διάρκεια ενός διεθνούς σεμιναρίου και επικεντρώνεται στους νέους και στην δημιουργία ενός υγιούς τρόπου ζωής, ψυχικά όσο και σωματικά και με αναφορά ενεργή συμμετοχή προκειμένου να περνούν εναλλακτικά μακριά από νόθες μορφές ψυχαγωγίας τον ελεύθερο τους χρόνο.
Η συμμετοχή των νέων συμβάλει στην δυνατότητα να αποφασίζουν μόνοι τους για το μέλλον τους και τις ζωές τους και αυτό αποτελεί το βασικό στοιχείο του προγράμματος. Τα βασικά χαρακτηριστικά περιλαμβάνουν την επαφή των νέων με καινούριες εμπειρίες και ευκαιρίες, την μάθηση σχετικά με την Ευρώπη, την επαφή με την μη τυπική μάθηση ως βασικό στοιχείο για το youth work, την ανάπτυξη προσωπικών δεξιοτήτων και πως να είναι επικεφαλής- ηγέτες και να αναλαμβάνουν ενεργό ρόλο στους οργανισμούς τους. Υπάρχουν νέοι που προέρχονται από διάφορα επίπεδα και διάφορα κοινωνικά στρώματα. Οι νέοι που συμμετέχουν έχουν λιγότερες κοινωνικές και οικονομικές δυνατότητες και αυτό το πρόγραμμα πραγματικά δίνει την δυνατότητα να αναπτύξουν αυτές τις ικανότητες και να έχουν περισσότερες ευκαιρίες προσωπικής εξέλιξης, ενεργούς συμμετοχής και εργασίας. Οι δραστηριότητες περιλαμβάνουν την συμμετοχή σε σωματικές δραστηριότητες, δραστηριότητες κριτικής σκέψης και "ακόνισμα" του μυαλού και συμμετοχή στο νεανικό πρόγραμμα ηγεσίας. H μεθοδολογία θα περιλαμβάνει την ομαδική εργασία, την μάθηση, τη δραστηριότητα πολυμέσων, τον προγραμματισμό και τη συμμετοχή στην ανάπτυξη προγραμμάτων. Το πρόγραμμα θα οδηγήσει τους νέους να κατανοήσουν  περισσότερα για τον εαυτό τους και για άλλους νέους από την Ευρώπη, θα οδηγήσει τους νέους να έχουν περισσότερη εμπιστοσύνη και κοινωνική ευαισθησία και να διαθέτουν κριτική στάση όσον αφορά τις ευκαιρίες και τις επιλογές που έχουν στη διάθεσή τους. Σημαντικός θα είναι και ο αντίκτυπος στους συμμετέχοντες οργανισμούς, οι οποίοι θα μάθουν περισσότερα σχετικά με τη συμμετοχή, τη χάραξη πολιτικής και τα οφέλη της διεθνούς εργασίας ως βασικό στοιχείο της έμπρακτης συμμετοχής των νέων μελών.
Η ανταλλαγή νέων θα πραγματοποιηθεί από στις 25/04/2018 έως και  01/05/2018 στη Φλώρινα, Ελλάδα, Περιφέρειας Δυτικής Μακεδονίας.

Delivery of 1+2 languages. Focus on French in school
Language training project for 2 teachers for immersion in spoken French.
Two participants, both with limited knowledge of French, but with an MLPS training.
The course is a 6 day immersion course in French language and culture.
The course will result in improved ability to speak French and therefore teach it to Primary aged pupils who in turn will have greater opportunity to develop their French accent and vocabulary.
Teachers will be better able to support parents and colleagues.
discover partners in France to communicate with.
Total travel costs: 550 euros
Total Individual support: 2240 euros
Total Course fees: 840 euros
Total organisational support: 700 euros

The project will allow the school to now have four teachers trainied in language and methodology to embed French into everyday teaching and learning at the school.
It will help the school follow the ethos of a Curriculum for Excellence, find partners abroad to work closely with to deliver this and allow pupils to use ICT to communicate with other schools in UK and abroad.
The project will  improve the competencies of the staff members by assisting them to acquire and learn new vocabulary, improve and develop new teaching practices and gain confidence and competence at delivering French within a Curriculum for Excellence. It will enhance understanding, awareness and appreciation of the culture of modern France.
The immersion training offers opportunities to develop new teaching methods and tools. It will develop the confidence of the participants to establish formal links with French schools and allow children from Scotland and France to develop friendships, and understand similarities and differences in school life and their wider culture.
The staff members identified have demonstrated passion for integrating French into their teaching through participation in the  Scottish Government 1 + 2 initiative and other modern language CPD activities. The training offers opportunities for the participants to improve their language competency and enhance teaching skills to deliver engaging French lessons to primary school aged children.
This will be achieved through assisting the participants to:
• Improve methodological expertise in the teaching of French to young learners
• Acquire materials and ideas suitable for the teaching of the French at primary level
• Develop cultural awareness and understanding of contemporary France including the education system 
• Improve competence and performance in speaking and teaching French 
• Use relevant, engaging internet and other ICT resources in their class.
The course will provide the participants with greater confidence and ability to teach Modern Foreign Languages and a greater cultural awareness which can be transferred to pupils. This will allow staff to teach French in a more ad hoc way, several times a week rather than just 1 session per week.
All new resources will be placed on a shared drive within the school, to help learning and teaching throughout the school.
The activities will raise awareness of the importance of languages and Europe within the school to pupils, staff, parents and other stakeholders.
Social media, brochures, blogs, press articles in the local newspapers, exhibitions and open events in school will all be used to promote greater awareness of French language learning in the school. Results of the training will have already been communicated to colleagues through presentations and/or workshops at staff training events.
These will impact: 
• Locally –  on staff, pupils and parents.
• Regionally – by transfer of skills within cluster groups
• Nationally – developing the ability to contribute to national language events
• European level – increasing European links with Primary/ Secondary schools

The project will allow the school to have two teachers training in language and methodology to embed French and Spanish into everyday teaching and learning at the school.It will help the school follow the ethos of a Curriculum for Excellence, find partners abroad to work closely with to deliver this and allow pupils to use ICT to communicate with other schools in UK and abroad.The project will  improve the competencies of the staff member by assisting him to acquire and learn new vocabulary, improve and develop new teaching practices and gain confidence and competence at delivering French within a Curriculum for Excellence. It will enhance understanding, awareness and appreciation of the culture of modern France.The immersion training offers opportunities to develop new teaching methods and tools. It will develop the confidence of the participant to establish formal links with Spanish and French schools and allow children from both Scotland, Spain andFrance to develop friendships and bonds and understand similarities and differences in school life and their wider culture.The staff members identified have demonstrated keen passion for integrating French and Spanish into their teaching through participation in the  Scottish Government 1 + 2 initiative and other modern language CPD activities. The training offers opportunities for the participant to improve his language competency and enhance his teaching skills to deliver engaging French lessons to primary school aged children.This will be achieved through assisting the participant to:• Improve methodological expertise in the teaching of French and Spanish to young learners• Acquire materials and ideas suitable for the teaching of the French and Spanish at primary level• Develop cultural awareness and understanding of contemporary France and Spain including the education system • Improve his competence and performance in speaking and teaching French and Spanish• Use relevant, engaging internet and other ICT resources in their class.The course will provide the participant with greater confidence and ability to teach Modern Foreign Languages and a greater cultural awareness which can be transferred to pupils. It will improve his teaching methodology for languages within the school and embed French and Spanish on a cross curriculum level. This will allow staff to start teaching French and Spanish in a more ad hoc way, several times a week rather than just 1 session per week.All new resources will be placed on a shared drive within the school, to help learning and teaching throughout the school.The activities will raise awareness of the importance of languages and Europe within the school to pupils, staff, parents and other stakeholders.There will be ongoing dissemination activities related to mobility to raise awareness.  It is anticipated that new CPD opportunities training materials will be created within school and the cluster. Social media, brochures, blogs, press articles in the local newspapers, exhibitions and open events in school will all be used to promote greater awareness of French and Spanish language learning in the school. Results of the training will have already been communicated to colleagues through presentations and/or workshops at staff training events.These will impact: • Locally –  on staff, pupils and parents.• Regionally – by transfer of skills within cluster groups• Nationally – developing the ability to contribute to national language events• European level – increasing European links with Primary/ Secondary schools

The French training project ( The French immersion courses) created by LFEE will give the participants an opportunity to develop their language teaching skills, improve their language knowledge and abilities and deepen their understanding of other cultures. These are essential skills to successfully deliver the recommendations of the L1+2 Modern Language policy that is being implemented in Angus schools. All knowledge and skills gained will enhance the learning experience of Isla pupils and staff as well as raise awareness of the importance of Modern Languages in the field of potential future employment.
The objectives are to improve the confidence and competence of the participants in order that they can take forward and support the L1+2 initiative across the staff team at Isla and with cluster colleagues. 
• To improve and enhance conversational French and to gain new ideas for the classroom.
• To develop and maintain a bank of resources to use within the school  ICT/Internet, books, songs and films.
• To develop cultural awareness and an understanding of modern day living in France.
• To improve pedagogy.

This application is for two members of staff. Isla is a small rural school so it is our intention that the applicants will cascade knowledge gained to other staff and will take both take lead roles in the development of language skills and knowledge within the school and associated cluster schools when the opportunity arises. One participant as the school’s French Coordinator for Isla will work with the Head Teacher to direct the development of the school aims. 
The week long French immersion courses will provide daily opportunities to gain further skills in Languages and cultural knowledge through studies of a range of pedagogical techniques. It will provide experiences as both teacher and pupil and complete immersion in the language and culture through visits to planned sites. All of these will greatly improve the participants’ individual skills in the effectiveness of teaching a modern language.

The intensive week long professional learning experience will provide the practical/interactive model of how to teach a modern foreign language effectively. It would be expected that the participants will deliver workshops to other staff at Isla to bolster the planned improvement work which is supported by Richard Talleron, Power Platform.
The experience will provide Isla staff strong links with practitioners in France and will increase our capacity to deliver French well through improved pedagogy, access to better resources and materials, ICT and knowledge of modern day France. We will use Assessment is for Learning (AiFL) approaches to check ongoing progress  and to help us set next step targets with pupils so that our decisions about children’s competencies are well placed and the pace of learning is well suited to ongoing achievements.

The potential longer term benefits are positive for pupils and staff. The French immersion courses will allow the staff at Isla to work with pupils in ways which will motivate them to learn and help them to understand the importance and relevance of learning a modern language in today’s global economy. 
At Isla we are dedicated to giving our pupils the very best life chances and our long term goal is to nurture well rounded young individuals who have a positive outlook to life both in and beyond their local and national environments
